1.General: Jacob heard that Laban's sons were saying, "Jacob has taken everything our father owned and has gained all this wealth from what belonged to our father."
1.Non-Denominational: Jacob heard that Laban's sons were saying, "Jacob has taken everything our father owned and has gained all this wealth from what belonged to our father."
1.Baptist: Jacob overhears Laban's sons grumbling, resentfully accusing Jacob of acquiring his wealth by taking what rightfully belonged to their father, Laban.
1.Catholic: Jacob becomes aware of the resentment brewing among Laban's sons. He overhears them saying, 'Jacob has taken all that was our father's, and from what was our father's he has gained all this wealth.' They view Jacob's prosperity not as earned or blessed by God, but as stolen from their inheritance.
1.Methodist: Jacob hears Laban's sons complaining that Jacob built his wealth by taking their father's property.
1.Lutheran: Jacob hears Laban's sons complaining that Jacob has taken Laban's possessions and built his wealth from Laban's property.
1.Presbyterian: Jacob hears Laban's sons complaining that his wealth was gained at the expense of their father.
1.Pentecostal: Jacob hears Laban's sons saying Jacob got rich from Laban's property.
1.Episcopalian/Anglican: Jacob learns Laban's sons are resentful, accusing him of acquiring his wealth from their father's property.
1.Orthodox: Jacob overhears Laban's sons expressing resentment, accusing him of amassing his wealth by misappropriating their father's assets.
1.Other: Jacob heard that Laban's sons were saying, "Jacob has taken everything our father owned and has gained all this wealth from what belonged to our father."
1.Prefer not to say: Jacob heard that Laban's sons were saying, "Jacob has taken everything our father owned and has gained all this wealth from what belonged to our father."

2.General: And Jacob noticed that Laban's attitude toward him was not what it had been.
2.Non-Denominational: And Jacob noticed that Laban's attitude toward him was not what it had been.
2.Baptist: Jacob also perceives a change in Laban himself; Laban's facial expression and demeanor towards Jacob are no longer friendly or favorable as before.
2.Catholic: Jacob personally observes a shift in Laban's own disposition towards him. Laban's 'face' (attitude, countenance) was no longer favorable towards Jacob as it had been previously.
2.Methodist: Jacob observes that Laban's attitude towards him has also turned unfavorable.
2.Lutheran: Jacob sees that Laban's attitude/face towards him is not like it was before.
2.Presbyterian: Jacob observes that Laban's attitude towards him has become less favorable.
2.Pentecostal: Jacob notices Laban's attitude towards him has changed for the worse.
2.Episcopalian/Anglican: Jacob perceives that Laban's attitude towards him is no longer favorable.
2.Orthodox: Jacob observes a distinct cooling in Laban's attitude towards him compared to previous times.
2.Other: And Jacob noticed that Laban's attitude toward him was not what it had been.
2.Prefer not to say: And Jacob noticed that Laban's attitude toward him was not what it had been.

3.General: The Lord said to Jacob, 'Go back to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you.'
3.Non-Denominational: The Lord said to Jacob, 'Go back to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you.'
3.Baptist: Amidst this growing tension, God speaks directly to Jacob, commanding him to return to Canaan ('the land of your fathers and to your kindred') and reaffirming the promise of His presence ('I will be with you').
3.Catholic: At this opportune moment of rising tension, the Lord directly commands Jacob: 'Return to the land of your fathers and to your kindred, and I will be with you.' This divine instruction confirms Jacob's own inclination and provides the crucial promise of God's continued presence and support for the journey.
3.Methodist: God commands Jacob to return to his homeland (Canaan) and relatives, promising His presence ('I will be with you').
3.Lutheran: Yahweh tells Jacob to return to the land of his fathers and relatives, promising to be with him.
3.Presbyterian: God instructs Jacob to return to his ancestral land, promising His presence.
3.Pentecostal: God tells Jacob to go back home, promising to be with him.
3.Episcopalian/Anglican: The Lord instructs Jacob to return to the land of his ancestors and relatives, promising His presence.
3.Orthodox: The Lord instructs Jacob to return to his ancestral homeland and relatives, assuring him of the divine presence.
3.Other: The Lord said to Jacob, 'Go back to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you.'
3.Prefer not to say: The Lord said to Jacob, 'Go back to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you.'.

4.General: So Jacob sent word to Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were.
4.Non-Denominational: So Jacob sent word to Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were.
4.Baptist: Jacob summons Rachel and Leah to meet him privately in the field among his flocks, away from Laban's household, to discuss his plan.
4.Catholic: Acting on God's command and his own assessment of the situation, Jacob summons Rachel and Leah to meet him discreetly in the field where his flocks are located, away from the main household and Laban's immediate influence.
4.Methodist: Jacob calls Rachel and Leah to meet him privately in the field with his flocks.
4.Lutheran: Jacob sends for Rachel and Leah to meet him in the field with his flock.
4.Presbyterian: Jacob summons Rachel and Leah to meet him in the field among his flocks.
4.Pentecostal: Jacob calls Rachel and Leah to the field.
4.Episcopalian/Anglican: Jacob summons Rachel and Leah to meet him in the field where his flocks are.
4.Orthodox: Jacob summons Rachel and Leah for a private consultation in the field where his flocks are pastured.
4.Other: So Jacob sent word to Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were.
4.Prefer not to say: So Jacob sent word to Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were.

5.General: He said to them, 'I see that your father's attitude toward me is not what it was before, but the God of my father has been with me.'
5.Non-Denominational: He said to them, 'I see that your father's attitude toward me is not what it was before, but the God of my father has been with me.'
5.Baptist: Jacob explains the situation to his wives: he observes their father Laban's changed, unfavorable attitude, but contrasts this with the consistent faithfulness of God ('the God of my father') who has been with him.
5.Catholic: Jacob explains his reasoning to his wives: 'I see that your father's face is not toward me as it was before.' He acknowledges the breakdown in the relationship with Laban but immediately affirms his reliance on a higher power: 'But the God of my father has been with me.'
5.Methodist: Jacob tells them he sees Laban's changed attitude but affirms that his father's God has been with him.
5.Lutheran: Jacob explains he sees Laban's negative attitude change, but affirms that the God of his father (Abraham/Isaac) has been with him.
5.Presbyterian: Jacob explains Laban's changed attitude but emphasizes that God has remained with him.
5.Pentecostal: Jacob explains Laban's changed attitude but says God has been with him.
5.Episcopalian/Anglican: Jacob explains to his wives that he perceives Laban's changed attitude, but affirms that the God of his father has been with him.
5.Orthodox: Jacob communicates to his wives his observation of Laban's altered demeanor, contrasting it with the steadfast presence of the God of his ancestors.
5.Other: He said to them, 'I see that your father's attitude toward me is not what it was before, but the God of my father has been with me.'
5.Prefer not to say: He said to them, 'I see that your father's attitude toward me is not what it was before, but the God of my father has been with me.'

6.General: You know that I've worked for your father with all my strength,
6.Non-Denominational: You know that I've worked for your father with all my strength,
6.Baptist: He reminds them of his own diligent and faithful service to Laban over the years, appealing to their personal knowledge of his hard work.
6.Catholic: Jacob appeals to their own experience as witnesses: 'You know that I have served your father with all my strength.' He emphasizes his dedication and effort during his long service.
6.Methodist: He reminds them they know he has served Laban faithfully and diligently.
6.Lutheran: He reminds them they know he has served Laban with all his strength.
6.Presbyterian: He reminds them of his diligent service to Laban.
6.Pentecostal: He reminds them he worked hard for Laban.
6.Episcopalian/Anglican: He reminds them that they know he has served Laban with all his strength.
6.Orthodox: He reminds them of his unwavering diligence and effort in serving Laban.
6.Other: You know that I've worked for your father with all my strength,
6.Prefer not to say: You know that I've worked for your father with all my strength,

7.General: yet your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times. However, God has not allowed him to harm me.
7.Non-Denominational: yet your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times. However, God has not allowed him to harm me.
7.Baptist: He accuses Laban of repeatedly cheating him by changing the terms of his wages multiple times ('ten times' signifying repeatedly). Despite Laban's attempts to exploit him, Jacob testifies that God providentially protected him from harm or loss.
7.Catholic: He explicitly accuses Laban of deceit and exploitation: 'Yet your father has cheated me and changed my wages ten times.' ('Ten times' likely means repeatedly or many times). However, Jacob credits divine protection for mitigating the damage: 'But God did not permit him to harm me.'
7.Methodist: He accuses Laban of cheating him by changing his wages repeatedly ('ten times') but states God protected him from harm.
7.Lutheran: He states Laban cheated him, changing his wages ten times (repeatedly), but God did not allow Laban to harm him.
7.Presbyterian: He recounts Laban's deceit in changing his wages repeatedly ('ten times'), but emphasizes God's protection prevented Laban from harming him.
7.Pentecostal: He says Laban cheated him by changing his wages ten times, but God protected him.
7.Episcopalian/Anglican: He accuses Laban of cheating him by changing his wages repeatedly ('ten times'), but asserts God prevented Laban from harming him.
7.Orthodox: He recounts Laban's repeated duplicity in altering his wages ('ten times' indicating frequency), while affirming God's providential protection prevented Laban from causing him significant harm.
7.Other: yet your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times. However, God has not allowed him to harm me.
7.Prefer not to say: yet your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times. However, God has not allowed him to harm me.

8.General: If he said, 'The speckled ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks gave birth to speckled young; and if he said, 'The streaked ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks bore streaked young.
8.Non-Denominational: If he said, 'The speckled ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks gave birth to speckled young; and if he said, 'The streaked ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks bore streaked young.
8.Baptist: Jacob illustrates God's intervention: whenever Laban tried to change the agreement to his own advantage (e.g., only speckled are Jacob's wages), God caused the flocks to produce precisely those kinds of offspring, frustrating Laban's schemes and blessing Jacob.
8.Catholic: Jacob provides specific examples of God's intervention turning Laban's schemes against him. Whenever Laban changed the terms (e.g., 'The speckled shall be your wages'), God providentially caused the flocks to bear offspring matching those new terms, ensuring Jacob still prospered despite Laban's attempts to limit his earnings.
8.Methodist: He gives examples of God's intervention: whatever type of animal Laban designated as Jacob's wages, the flocks miraculously produced those specific types, thwarting Laban's attempts to reduce Jacob's share.
8.Lutheran: He gives examples: if Laban said speckled would be Jacob's wages, the flocks bore speckled; if streaked, they bore streaked.
8.Presbyterian: He illustrates God's providence: whatever Laban designated as Jacob's wage, God ensured the flocks produced accordingly.
8.Pentecostal: He explains how God made the flocks produce whatever Laban set as Jacob's wages.
8.Episcopalian/Anglican: He illustrates how God intervened: whatever Laban designated as Jacob's wages (speckled or streaked), the flocks bore accordingly.
8.Orthodox: Jacob provides examples of divine intervention: regardless of how Laban altered the terms of payment (speckled or streaked), God ensured the flocks produced offspring matching those terms, thereby blessing Jacob.
8.Other: If he said, 'The speckled ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks gave birth to speckled young; and if he said, 'The streaked ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks bore streaked young.
8.Prefer not to say: If he said, 'The speckled ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks gave birth to speckled young; and if he said, 'The streaked ones will be your wages,' then all the flocks bore streaked young.

9.General: So God has taken away your father's livestock and has given them to me.
9.Non-Denominational: So God has taken away your father's livestock and has given them to me.
9.Baptist: Jacob explicitly attributes the transfer of wealth not to his own cunning or Laban's sons' accusations of theft, but to God's sovereign action: God took Laban's livestock and gave it to him.
9.Catholic: Jacob explicitly interprets this transfer of wealth as a divine act: 'Thus God has taken away the livestock of your father and given them to me.' He sees it not primarily as the result of his own strategy or Laban's mismanagement, but as God justly reallocating the wealth.
9.Methodist: Jacob concludes God Himself took Laban's livestock and gave it to him.
9.Lutheran: Jacob states plainly that God took Laban's livestock and gave it to him (Jacob).
9.Presbyterian: Jacob explicitly states God transferred the livestock wealth from Laban to him.
9.Pentecostal: Jacob says God took Laban's livestock and gave it to him.
9.Episcopalian/Anglican: Jacob explicitly attributes the transfer of wealth to God taking Laban's livestock and giving it to him.
9.Orthodox: Jacob directly attributes the shift in wealth to divine action, asserting that God appropriated Laban's livestock and bestowed it upon him.
9.Other: So God has taken away your father's livestock and has given them to me.
9.Prefer not to say: So God has taken away your father's livestock and has given them to me.

10.General: In breeding season I once had a dream in which I looked up and saw that the male goats mating with the flock were streaked, speckled or spotted.
10.Non-Denominational: In breeding season I once had a dream in which I looked up and saw that the male goats mating with the flock were streaked, speckled or spotted.
10.Baptist: Jacob recounts a dream he had during breeding season where he saw that the male goats mating were the very types (streaked, speckled, spotted) that produced his wages, revealing divine insight into the process.
10.Catholic: Jacob now shares a previously unmentioned dream, revealing the divine insight behind his success. He dreamt during the breeding season and saw that the male goats actively mating were precisely the streaked, speckled, and spotted kind – the ones producing offspring beneficial to him.
10.Methodist: Jacob recounts a dream where he saw the male goats mating were the streaked, speckled, and spotted type (revealing God's hand in the process).
10.Lutheran: Jacob describes a dream during breeding season where he saw the male goats mating were streaked, speckled, and spotted.
10.Presbyterian: Jacob recounts a dream revealing that the successful breeding males were the marked ones.
10.Pentecostal: Jacob shares a dream where he saw the marked males mating.
10.Episcopalian/Anglican: Jacob recounts a dream during breeding season where he saw that the male goats mating were streaked, speckled, or spotted.
10.Orthodox: Jacob relates a dream wherein he observed during mating season that the breeding males were precisely those with the markings designated for his wages.
10.Other: In breeding season I once had a dream in which I looked up and saw that the male goats mating with the flock were streaked, speckled or spotted.
10.Prefer not to say: In breeding season I once had a dream in which I looked up and saw that the male goats mating with the flock were streaked, speckled or spotted.

11.General: The angel of God said to me in the dream, 'Jacob.' I answered, 'Here I am.'
11.Non-Denominational: The angel of God said to me in the dream, 'Jacob.' I answered, 'Here I am.'
11.Baptist: He further explains that the angel of God spoke to him within this dream, calling him by name.
11.Catholic: Within the dream, the 'angel of God' addressed Jacob directly, calling his name. Jacob responded, indicating his attentiveness ('Here I am').
11.Methodist: The angel of God spoke to him in the dream.
11.Lutheran: The angel of God spoke to him in the dream, calling his name.
11.Presbyterian: He adds that the angel of God spoke to him in the dream.
11.Pentecostal: The angel of God spoke to Jacob in the dream.
11.Episcopalian/Anglican: The angel of God addressed him in the dream.
11.Orthodox: He clarifies that the Angel of God addressed him within this dream.
11.Other: The angel of God said to me in the dream, 'Jacob.' I answered, 'Here I am.'
11.Prefer not to say: The angel of God said to me in the dream, 'Jacob.' I answered, 'Here I am.'

12.General: And he said, 'Look up and see that all the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled or spotted, for I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.'
12.Non-Denominational: And he said, 'Look up and see that all the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled or spotted, for I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.'
12.Baptist: The angel confirmed the observation in the dream (the marked males were breeding) and explicitly linked God's intervention to Laban's mistreatment: God saw Laban's injustice and was acting on Jacob's behalf.
12.Catholic: The angel explicitly directed Jacob's attention to the breeding males ('Lift up your eyes and see, all the goats that leap upon the flock are streaked, speckled, and mottled') and then explained the reason: 'for I have seen all that Laban is doing to you.' This confirms God's awareness of Laban's injustice and His active intervention to counteract it.
12.Methodist: The angel pointed out the marked males were mating and stated this was happening because God saw Laban's mistreatment of Jacob.
12.Lutheran: The angel told him to see that the mating males were marked, explaining this was because God had seen Laban's mistreatment of Jacob.
12.Presbyterian: The angel confirmed the observation and explained it was God's response to Laban's mistreatment of Jacob.
12.Pentecostal: The angel confirmed the marked males were mating because God saw how Laban treated Jacob.
12.Episcopalian/Anglican: The angel confirmed that the mating males were marked and explained this was because God had seen Laban's unfair treatment of Jacob.
12.Orthodox: The Angel confirmed Jacob's observation about the breeding males and explicitly stated this divine orchestration was a response to God's awareness of Laban's unjust treatment of Jacob.
12.Other: And he said, 'Look up and see that all the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled or spotted, for I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.'
12.Prefer not to say: And he said, 'Look up and see that all the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled or spotted, for I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.'

13.General: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and where you made a vow to me. Now leave this land at once and go back to your native land.'
13.Non-Denominational: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and where you made a vow to me. Now leave this land at once and go back to your native land.'
13.Baptist: The angel identifies himself as 'the God of Bethel,' reminding Jacob of his earlier encounter, the consecrated pillar, and the vow made there. This divine voice now commands Jacob to leave Harran immediately and return to Canaan.
13.Catholic: Crucially, the divine messenger identifies Himself: 'I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and made a vow to me.' This connects the current instruction to Jacob's foundational experience of God's covenant promise at Bethel (Gen 28). The command follows logically: 'Now arise, go out from this land and return to the land of your birth.'
13.Methodist: The angel identifies Himself as the God Jacob met at Bethel (recalling the pillar and vow) and commands Jacob to leave immediately and return home.
13.Lutheran: The angel identifies himself as the God of Bethel (recalling Jacob's vow there) and commands Jacob to leave Laban's land and return to his native land.
13.Presbyterian: The angel identifies Himself as the God of Bethel, recalling Jacob's vow, and commands him to leave Laban's land and return home.
13.Pentecostal: The angel identifies himself as the God of Bethel and commands Jacob to go home immediately.
13.Episcopalian/Anglican: The angel identifies Himself as the God of Bethel, reminding Jacob of his vow, and commands him to leave at once and return to his native land.
13.Orthodox: The divine messenger identifies Himself as the God encountered at Bethel, referencing the anointed pillar and Jacob's vow, and commands Jacob's immediate departure and return to his homeland.
13.Other: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and where you made a vow to me. Now leave this land at once and go back to your native land.'
13.Prefer not to say: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and where you made a vow to me. Now leave this land at once and go back to your native land.'

14.General: Then Rachel and Leah replied, 'Do we still have any share in the inheritance of our father's estate?'
14.Non-Denominational: Then Rachel and Leah replied, 'Do we still have any share in the inheritance of our father's estate?'
14.Baptist: Rachel and Leah respond to Jacob, beginning with a rhetorical question expressing their alienation from their father's household: they no longer expect any inheritance or portion from Laban.
14.Catholic: Rachel and Leah respond jointly and readily agree with Jacob's assessment. They begin by highlighting their own disenfranchisement: 'Is there any portion or inheritance left to us in our father's house?' They feel they have no remaining stake or future there.
14.Methodist: Rachel and Leah respond, questioning if they have any inheritance left in Laban's household.
14.Lutheran: Rachel and Leah ask rhetorically if they still have any portion or inheritance in Laban's house.
14.Presbyterian: Rachel and Leah respond by questioning whether they have any remaining inheritance in Laban's house.
14.Pentecostal: Rachel and Leah ask if they have any inheritance left from Laban.
14.Episcopalian/Anglican: Rachel and Leah respond, questioning if they still have any share or inheritance in their father's house.
14.Orthodox: Rachel and Leah concur with Jacob, rhetorically asking if any portion or inheritance remains for them within their father's estate.
14.Other: Then Rachel and Leah replied, 'Do we still have any share in the inheritance of our father's estate?'
14.Prefer not to say: Then Rachel and Leah replied, 'Do we still have any share in the inheritance of our father's estate?'

15.General: They feel Laban treats them like foreigners, having sold them and used up the money paid for them (referring to Jacob's labor).
15.Non-Denominational: They feel Laban treats them like foreigners, having sold them and used up the money paid for them (referring to Jacob's labor).
15.Baptist: They feel Laban treats them like foreigners, not daughters. They accuse him of essentially 'selling' them (using Jacob's extensive labor, which served as their bride price) and then consuming that wealth himself instead of setting it aside for them or their dowry, as custom might dictate.
15.Catholic: They elaborate on their feeling of alienation: 'Are we not regarded by him as foreigners? For he has sold us, and he has indeed consumed our money (the bride price Jacob paid through labor).' They feel Laban treated them as commodities, benefiting from their marriage price (Jacob's 14 years of service) without providing them the security or dowry expected.
15.Methodist: They feel Laban treats them as foreigners, having 'sold' them (benefited from Jacob's service as bride price) and used the proceeds himself.
15.Lutheran: They ask if Laban doesn't regard them as foreigners, since he 'sold' them and used up the money (Jacob's labor/bride price).
15.Presbyterian: They complain Laban treats them as foreigners, having 'sold' them (through Jacob's service) and consumed the bride price himself.
15.Pentecostal: They say Laban treats them like foreigners, having sold them and used the money.
15.Episcopalian/Anglican: They ask if Laban does not regard them as foreigners, having 'sold' them and used up the bride price himself.
15.Orthodox: They articulate their sense of estrangement, stating Laban treats them as foreigners, having effectively sold them and consumed the bride price (Jacob's labor) himself.
15.Other: They feel Laban treats them like foreigners, having sold them and used up the money paid for them (referring to Jacob's labor).
15.Prefer not to say: They feel Laban treats them like foreigners, having sold them and used up the money paid for them (referring to Jacob's labor).

16.General: Surely all the wealth that God took away from our father belongs to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you.'
16.Non-Denominational: Surely all the wealth that God took away from our father belongs to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you.'

16.Catholic: Based on Laban's actions, they conclude that the wealth God transferred from Laban to Jacob rightfully belongs to them and their children ('Surely all the wealth which God has taken away from our father belongs to us and to our children'). They see Jacob's gain as their rightful portion. Consequently, they give Jacob their full support: 'Now then, whatever God has said to you, do.'
16.Methodist: They conclude the wealth God transferred from Laban to Jacob rightfully belongs to them and their children, and urge Jacob to obey God's command.
16.Lutheran: They assert the wealth God took from Laban belongs to them and their children, urging Jacob to do whatever God told him.
16.Presbyterian: They assert that the wealth God transferred rightfully belongs to them and their children, and encourage Jacob to obey God.
16.Pentecostal: They claim the wealth God took from Laban belongs to them and their children, telling Jacob to obey God.
16.Episcopalian/Anglican: They assert that the wealth God transferred from Laban rightfully belongs to them and their children, and urge Jacob to do whatever God has instructed.
16.Orthodox: They conclude that the wealth divinely transferred from Laban rightfully belongs to them and their offspring, thereby wholeheartedly endorsing Jacob's decision to follow God's directive.
16.Other: Surely all the wealth that God took away from our father belongs to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you.'

19.General: When Laban had gone to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father's household gods.
19.Non-Denominational: When Laban had gone to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father's household gods.
19.Baptist: Taking advantage of Laban's absence (he was away shearing sheep, a time-consuming task often done at a distance), Rachel secretly steals Laban's 'teraphim' (household idols or gods). Her motives are debated (sentiment, belief in their power, claim to inheritance, spite).
19.Catholic: While Laban is preoccupied with sheep shearing (an activity that often took shepherds some distance away), Rachel seizes the opportunity to steal her father's 'household gods' (teraphim). These were likely small idols representing family ancestors or deities, believed to provide protection, guidance, or legitimacy for inheritance claims. Rachel's motives remain ambiguous.
19.Methodist: While Laban is away shearing sheep, Rachel steals his household gods (teraphim), possibly for protection, inheritance rights, or out of lingering pagan belief.
19.Lutheran: While Laban is away shearing sheep, Rachel stole his household gods (teraphim).
